document_metadata.title: Uncertainty Register - Epistemic Coherence Unknowns and Unknowables

uncertainty_register.unknown: Executive contradiction awareness and acknowledgment—which executives (CEO, CFO, CRO, COO) aware of which contradictions (CRM profitability overstatement, satisfaction measurement absence, customer count ambiguity, data quality dual standard), whether executives acknowledge contradictions to each other in executive team discussions, whether contradictions explicitly managed or implicitly tolerated through silence
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot determine whether contradictions organizationally acknowledged or unrecognized—if executives aware and acknowledge contradictions to each other, contradictions represent conscious trade-offs organization explicitly manages (tolerance intentional, organizational capability to resolve exists but choice made not to), if executives unaware or don't acknowledge to each other, contradictions represent organizational blind spots or unexamined defaults (tolerance inadvertent, organizational capability to resolve uncertain). Cannot assess contradiction resolution likelihood—if awareness high and acknowledged, resolution possible through executive will and resource allocation, if awareness low or unacknowledged, resolution requires first awareness-building then capability-building making resolution more difficult and time-consuming. Affects acquirer management assessment—if executives aware of contradictions and tolerate them, acquirer questions executive judgment or organizational capability, if executives unaware, acquirer questions management systems and information visibility. Affects post-close integration planning—if awareness high, acquirer can engage executives on contradiction resolution directly (executives understand problem and can participate in solutions), if awareness low, acquirer must first educate on contradictions before engaging on solutions (awareness-building prerequisite adds time and political complexity to integration). Affects accountability assignment—if COO aware satisfaction unmeasured but didn't prioritize measurement infrastructure, COO accountable for measurement absence, if COO unaware satisfaction external truth deteriorating, COO not accountable for absence (organizational system didn't surface information), accountability clarity requires awareness assessment.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Executive interviews with specific contradiction probing: (1) CRM accuracy awareness—ask CRO 'What is CRM profitability estimate accuracy? How do you account for CRM accuracy in decisions?' (aware CRO would quantify overstatement and describe validation or adjustment processes, unaware CRO would claim CRM accurate or not know accuracy level). (2) Satisfaction measurement awareness—ask COO 'How do you measure customer satisfaction? What is current satisfaction trend?' (aware COO would acknowledge measurement absence and describe alternative satisfaction signals used or explain measurement absence decision rationale, unaware COO would claim satisfaction measured or be surprised by measurement absence question). (3) Customer count awareness—ask CFO and CRO 'How many customers does Rackspace have? How is customer defined?' (aware executives would acknowledge count depends on methodology and explain divergence across financial/territory/operational counts, unaware executives would provide single count without acknowledging ambiguity). (4) Finance adjustment awareness—ask COO 'How does your operational forecast relate to CFO external guidance? Does CFO adjust your forecast?' (aware COO would describe adjustment process and magnitude, unaware COO would claim forecasts aligned or be surprised by adjustment question). Executive team meeting minutes review: Do contradictions surface in executive discussions? (e.g., 'CRM shows X profitability but delivery says Y'—indicates awareness and acknowledgment, absence of such discussions suggests contradictions not explicitly addressed). Board presentation materials prepared by executives: Do executives present contradictions to Board or present coherent single truth? (presenting contradictions indicates executive awareness and acknowledgment, presenting single truth without caveats indicates either unawareness or conscious choice to filter contradictions from Board). Executive decision documents: Do internal memos or decision papers acknowledge data limitations? (e.g., 'CRM profitability estimates historically overstate by X%, proposal accounts for expected overstatement'—indicates awareness).

uncertainty_register.unknown: Board awareness of operational information contradictions—whether Board aware of CRM profitability overstatement, satisfaction measurement absence, customer count ambiguity, data quality issues documented Stage 7.2, 7.3, 7.4, whether Board aware of information asymmetries and latency patterns documented Stage 7.5, 7.6, whether Board briefed on epistemic contradictions or Board operates assuming information coherence
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess Board operational oversight adequacy without knowing Board information awareness—if Board aware of contradictions and chooses not to require resolution, Board operational governance prioritization questionable (Board accepts contradictions as acceptable trade-offs, Board oversight adequate but priorities different from acquirer expectations), if Board unaware of contradictions, Board operational visibility insufficient for effective oversight (management filters operational contradictions from Board, Board governance impaired by information gap). Cannot evaluate Board fiduciary diligence—if Board unaware satisfaction unmeasured, customer counts ambiguous, CRM data inaccurate, Board cannot govern customer strategy, data integrity, operational capability adequately (Board fiduciary duty requires material information awareness, contradictions material to customer retention risk, pipeline valuation, operational decision quality). Cannot determine contradiction disclosure obligations—if Board aware of contradictions affecting external metrics (pipeline value, customer counts, margin drivers), Board may have disclosure obligations to investors, if Board unaware, disclosure gap may exist but Board not accountable (management responsible for Board information provision). Affects acquirer Board continuity decisions—if Board aware of contradictions and tolerated them, acquirer may question Board member retention post-close (Board oversight standards misaligned with acquirer expectations), if Board unaware, acquirer may retain Board but strengthen Board information provision (Board members capable but management filtered information). Affects acquirer management credibility assessment—if Board unaware despite management interaction, management credibility with Board uncertain (does management proactively inform Board of operational challenges or filter information presenting optimistic view?), credibility assessment affects post-close management retention and authority.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Board materials review for multiple quarters: (1) Do Board presentations include data quality caveats? (e.g., 'pipeline value based on CRM estimates subject to X% historical overstatement', 'customer satisfaction not systematically measured, retention risk assessment based on churn trends and external platform monitoring'—caveats indicate Board awareness). (2) Do Board materials present contradictions or single coherent truth? (presenting satisfaction external truth and internal measurement absence indicates awareness, presenting only brand claim 'Fanatical Support' without satisfaction data indicates unawareness or filtering). (3) Do Board financial presentations include operational detail enabling contradiction visibility? (deal-level profitability data would surface CRM-delivery gap, satisfaction metrics would surface measurement absence, customer count methodology disclosures would surface ambiguity). Board meeting minutes review: (1) Do Board questions probe data quality? (e.g., 'How confident are we in pipeline value? What is CRM accuracy?', 'How do we measure customer satisfaction? What is current satisfaction state?'—questions indicate Board seeks contradiction information). (2) Do Board discussions reference contradictions or assume coherence? (discussions about pipeline value divergence between sales and finance indicate awareness, discussions assuming pipeline value single truth indicate unawareness). Board committee structures: Does Board have audit committee reviewing data quality and information architecture? (audit committee data quality oversight would increase Board contradiction awareness likelihood). Board member interviews: Direct questions about awareness—'Are you aware of CRM profitability estimate accuracy? Customer satisfaction measurement practices? Customer count definitions?'—Board member responses reveal awareness levels.
uncertainty_register.knowability_constraint: Board awareness may be UNKNOWABLE without Board member access—if Board materials filtered by management and Board minutes confidential, external analysis cannot determine Board awareness definitively. Acquirer diligence with Board member interviews can reduce uncertainty, but pre-signing Board access may be limited. Board awareness critical for acquirer risk assessment but may remain uncertain until post-signing Board engagement or post-close when acquirer gains full Board material access.

uncertainty_register.unknown: CEO walk away policy profitability assessment methodology and truth source—which profitability truth CEO uses when reviewing deals under Q4 2024 walk away policy (CRM sales estimate, delivery cost assessment, finance adjustment, or independent CEO profitability analysis), how CEO profitability assessment differs from three existing truths, why CEO assessment needed if existing truths sufficient, how CEO obtains profitability data not visible to functional executives at T2 commitment
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess walk away policy effectiveness without knowing CEO assessment methodology—if CEO uses CRM truth (sales estimate), policy ineffective because CRM 13-15% overstatement means CEO reviews on same inaccurate data that enabled unprofitable deals to progress T0-T2, if CEO uses delivery truth (cost reality), policy partially effective but timing T5 post-signature means customer committed before CEO sees delivery truth creating relationship damage, if CEO uses finance adjustment, policy effectiveness depends on adjustment accuracy (if finance adjustment corrects for CRM overstatement accurately, CEO sees correct profitability, if finance adjustment unrelated to CRM accuracy or insufficient, CEO profitability assessment still inaccurate), if CEO conducts independent assessment, policy most effective but CEO bandwidth burden highest (independent assessment requires CEO deal analysis T5 duplicating sales T0 and delivery T3 analysis consuming CEO time per Stage 4.2 bottleneck). Cannot determine whether policy sustainable—if CEO assessment methodology resource-intensive (independent analysis requiring hours per deal), deal volume scalability questionable (high deal volume makes policy unsustainable from CEO bandwidth constraints), if CEO assessment methodology lightweight (CRM data review taking minutes per deal), scalability higher but effectiveness questionable if using same inaccurate CRM data. Cannot evaluate policy necessity—if CEO sees profitability truth not visible to functional executives, policy addresses information asymmetry (CEO has information CRO/COO/CFO lack, CEO review adds value), if CEO sees same truths as functional executives, policy addresses authority not information (functional executives have information but lack authority to block deals, CEO authority needed not CEO information), policy necessity rationale affects organization design solutions (if information gap, solution is information sharing improving functional executive visibility, if authority gap, solution is authority delegation enabling functional executives to block without CEO escalation). Affects profitability truth reconciliation possibility—if CEO assessment represents fourth truth diverging from CRM/delivery/finance, contradiction worsens (now four profitability truths not three, CEO truth adds complexity not resolution), if CEO assessment reconciles existing truths into single validated assessment, CEO could be model for systematic reconciliation scalable beyond CEO individual review.
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Walk away policy documentation review: (1) Policy procedures—does policy describe CEO data sources? (e.g., 'CEO reviews CRM opportunity detail, delivery technical assessment, finance profitability analysis'—indicates CEO sees multiple truths and reconciles, or 'CEO reviews CRM profitability estimate and customer strategic fit'—indicates CEO primarily uses CRM truth with qualitative overlay). (2) Policy decision criteria—what profitability threshold or assessment framework CEO uses? (quantitative threshold like 'deals below X% margin rejected' indicates CEO quantitative truth assessment, qualitative criteria like 'strategic fit and relationship quality' indicates CEO uses non-profitability factors supplementing profitability truth). CEO walk away decisions sample analysis: (1) Review deals accepted vs rejected—do rejected deals have common characteristics in CRM data? (if rejected deals CRM profitability higher than acceptance threshold, CEO sees truth beyond CRM, if rejected deals CRM profitability below threshold, CEO may be using CRM truth with threshold enforcement). (2) Compare rejected deal CRM profitability to delivery assessed profitability if available—does CEO rejection align with delivery assessment or CRM assessment? (CEO-delivery alignment indicates CEO sees delivery truth, CEO-CRM alignment indicates CEO uses sales truth). CEO time allocation tracking: How much time does CEO spend per deal review? (hours per deal indicates independent assessment, minutes per deal indicates CRM data review, time investment reveals assessment methodology intensity). CEO interviews: 'How do you assess deal profitability under walk away policy? What data sources do you use? How does your assessment differ from sales CRM estimate or delivery cost assessment?' (CEO response reveals methodology and truth source directly).

uncertainty_register.unknown: Finance forecast adjustment methodology, magnitude, and operations communication—how finance adjusts operational forecasts for external guidance (what adjustment steps, what data inputs, what quantitative methodology), how much finance adjusts (adjustment magnitude as percentage of operational forecast, adjustment by segment or aggregate), whether finance communicates adjustment to operations proactively (adjustment shared before external publication, adjustment methodology explained, operations input solicited) or operations discovers adjustment through external guidance publication
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess operations-finance misalignment severity without knowing adjustment magnitude—if adjustment small (5-10% of operational forecast), misalignment limited and execution risk low, if adjustment large (20-30%+), misalignment material and execution risk high (operations staffed for operational forecast, measured on external guidance significantly different, systematic underperformance or over-resourcing from misalignment scale). Cannot evaluate finance adjustment accuracy and value—if adjustment corrects for known operational forecast biases (CRM overstatement, operations optimism, historical miss patterns), adjustment adds value improving external guidance accuracy, if adjustment ad hoc or judgment-based without empirical methodology, adjustment accuracy uncertain and may introduce new inaccuracy (finance guess replacing operations estimate, neither grounded in empirical validation). Cannot determine operations-finance relationship quality—if finance communicates adjustment proactively with methodology transparency, operations can align execution to external commitments (operations trusts finance adjustment as collaborative, operations understands adjustment rationale enabling operational planning adjustment), if finance adjusts opaquely without operations communication, operations-finance relationship tension from surprise and perceived skepticism (operations discovers adjustment post-facto creating trust erosion, operations perceives finance adjustment as skepticism of operations capability). Cannot assess forecast process maturity—if adjustment methodology documented, communicated, empirically grounded, forecast process mature (systematic, transparent, improvable over time through methodology refinement), if adjustment undocumented and opaque per Stage 7.2, forecast process immature (ad hoc, personality-dependent, not transferable across finance personnel, difficult to improve without methodology visibility). Affects acquirer forecast integration planning—if Rackspace finance adjustment practice differs from acquirer forecast process (acquirer collaborative operations-finance forecasting vs Rackspace sequential adjustment), integration requires process redesign, if adjustment magnitude large, acquirer must determine whether to continue adjustment (accept operations optimism and adjust) or eliminate adjustment through operations forecast improvement (improve operations accuracy to eliminate adjustment need).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Finance forecasting process documentation: (1) Adjustment methodology steps and timing—when does finance receive operations forecast, what analysis does finance conduct, what adjustments applied and why, how long does adjustment take, when is adjusted guidance finalized? (2) Adjustment quantitative methodology—what adjustment factors or formulas applied? (historical accuracy adjustments, pipeline discounts, margin conservatism factors, customer count reconciliation—specific methodologies reveal adjustment empirical grounding vs judgment-based). (3) Operations communication protocol—is operations informed of adjustment? when? how? (email with adjustment explanation, joint operations-finance meeting reviewing adjustment, no communication with operations discovering through external guidance publication—protocol reveals transparency level). Historical forecast analysis: (1) Retrospective comparison of operations forecast, finance external guidance, actual results over multiple quarters—reveals adjustment magnitude (guidance-operations differential), adjustment accuracy (guidance-actual differential vs operations-actual differential—if finance adjustment improves accuracy, guidance closer to actual than operations forecast, if adjustment ineffective, guidance no closer or further from actual), adjustment consistency (does adjustment magnitude vary significantly quarter-to-quarter suggesting ad hoc methodology, or stable suggesting systematic approach). Operations-finance meeting records: Are there forecast alignment meetings documented? What is discussed? (meetings with adjustment discussion indicate collaborative process, meeting absence or adjustment topic absence indicates sequential opacity). Finance and operations executive interviews: 'How does operational forecast become external guidance? What adjustment does finance make? Why? How is adjustment communicated to operations? Do operations and finance align on forecast before external publication?' (executive responses reveal process transparency and collaboration level).

uncertainty_register.unknown: CRM data quality tolerance rationale and organizational decision history—whether 13-15% profitability overstatement organizationally acknowledged and accepted through explicit decision (leadership evaluated data quality improvement costs vs benefits and chose to tolerate overstatement) or overstatement unexamined default (never analyzed, never decided, persists through organizational inertia), whether data quality improvement considered and rejected (improvement costs assessed and deemed prohibitive, accuracy-velocity trade-off explicitly evaluated with velocity prioritized) or never considered (data quality not on organizational agenda, improvement possibility not evaluated), whether sales data entry validation attempted historically and failed (delivery validation tried and abandoned as ineffective or too slow, CRM validation tooling implemented and circumvented) or never attempted (validation gap persists because validation never tried not because tried and failed)
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess organizational data quality maturity without knowing decision history—if overstatement acknowledged and accepted through explicit decision, organization data-sophisticated (understands data quality issues, consciously manages quality-velocity trade-offs, capable of data quality improvement if priorities change), if overstatement unexamined default, organization data-unsophisticated (data quality not managed, trade-offs not understood, data quality improvement capability uncertain). Cannot evaluate data quality improvement feasibility—if improvement considered and rejected as prohibitive cost, acquirer may face same cost barriers post-close (improvement difficult and expensive regardless of ownership, post-close data quality remediation challenging), if improvement never considered, acquirer may find improvement feasible with organizational prioritization (costs not as prohibitive as feared, improvement possible with standard data quality practices not requiring extraordinary investment). Cannot determine sales resistance to data quality improvement—if validation attempted and failed from sales circumvention, sales culture resistant to data quality discipline (sales values velocity over accuracy strongly, validation compliance difficult to achieve and sustain), if validation never attempted, sales resistance uncertain (may accept validation if framed appropriately and implemented smoothly, or may resist similar to hypothetical failed attempt—uncertainty about cultural barrier height). Cannot assess executive accountability for data quality—if overstatement acknowledged at executive level and tolerated, executives accountable for decision to accept inaccuracy (CRO accountable for CRM quality, executives collectively accountable for tolerance decision), if overstatement unacknowledged, executives not accountable for unawareness (accountability requires awareness, if data quality never surfaced to executive level, executives cannot be accountable for managing what they don't know exists). Affects post-close data quality remediation planning—if improvement previously attempted and failed, acquirer must design remediation learning from past failure (understand why past attempt failed, design remediation addressing past failure root causes), if improvement never attempted, acquirer can design remediation without past failure constraints (clean slate for data quality program design, but also no organizational learning from past attempts to inform design).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Historical initiative review: (1) Search for past data quality improvement initiatives in project records, executive communications, consultant reports—have data quality programs been attempted? when? what scope? what outcomes? (past initiatives documented indicate explicit data quality engagement, absence indicates default inertia). (2) Search for CRM validation tooling or process implementations—have validation workflows been built in CRM? when implemented? still active or disabled? (disabled validation indicates attempted-and-failed or attempted-and-circumvented, absence indicates never attempted). Executive decision records: (1) Have executives discussed CRM accuracy in meetings or memos? (discussions documented indicate awareness, decision rationale may be documented—e.g., 'CRM accuracy improvement would slow sales cycle X%, decided not to prioritize'—explicit decision, or discussions note problem without resolution plan indicating awareness without decision). (2) Have Board materials included data quality topics? (Board data quality discussion indicates executive awareness and prioritization, absence indicates data quality not executive/Board agenda item). Sales operations records: (1) How is sales compensation calculated? Are CRM bookings audited or validated before commission payment? (audit/validation process indicates data quality control attempt, audit findings would reveal accuracy issues, no audit indicates bookings trusted without validation). (2) Are there CRM data quality metrics or scorecards? (metrics tracked indicate data quality consciously managed even if not meeting targets, metrics absence indicates data quality not measured therefore not managed). Interviews with long-tenure employees: 'Has CRM accuracy been a topic in your time here? Have there been initiatives to improve CRM data quality? What happened to those initiatives?' (employee institutional memory reveals past attempts and organizational data quality engagement history).

uncertainty_register.unknown: Satisfaction measurement absence decision history and rationale—whether satisfaction measurement considered and explicitly rejected (measurement infrastructure scoped, costs assessed, decision made not to implement based on cost-benefit or other rationale), measurement attempted and failed (pilot conducted, failed from low response rates or implementation challenges, abandoned), or measurement never seriously considered (satisfaction measurement not on organizational radar, measurement absence default not decision)
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess organizational customer-centricity without knowing measurement decision history—if measurement considered and rejected based on explicit rationale (e.g., cost prohibitive, response rate challenges insurmountable, measurement wouldn't inform decisions), organization customer-aware but measurement-skeptical (understands customer satisfaction importance but questions measurement value), if measurement never considered, organization customer-unaware (customer satisfaction not organizational priority, measurement absence reflects customer-centricity deficit not measurement skepticism). Cannot evaluate measurement implementation feasibility post-close—if measurement attempted and failed, acquirer faces same implementation challenges (low response rate if that was past failure, implementation complexity if that was past barrier), acquirer must design implementation learning from past failure, if measurement never attempted, acquirer implementation not constrained by past failure (can implement standard NPS/CSAT practices without organizational baggage from past failed attempt). Cannot determine accountability for measurement absence—if measurement considered at executive level and rejected, executives accountable for decision (COO or CRO decision not to measure, decision rationale may be sound or questionable but decision was made), if measurement never surfaced to executive level, executives not accountable for absence (measurement gap organizational not executive—gap persists because never prioritized to executive agenda not because executive decided against). Cannot assess 'Fanatical Support' brand-satisfaction contradiction awareness—if measurement considered, organization aware satisfaction unmeasured and aware brand claim not grounded in measured reality (contradiction conscious, brand claim persistence despite measurement absence represents deliberate choice to maintain brand claim without empirical support), if measurement never considered, organization may be unaware of contradiction (brand claim believed sincerely without realizing claim not validated by measurement, contradiction inadvertent not conscious). Affects post-close brand strategy and measurement implementation—if past measurement attempt failed, acquirer brand strategy requires addressing past failure root causes (if response rate problem, acquirer must solve response rate to validate brand claim, if cost problem, acquirer must justify measurement investment), if measurement never attempted, acquirer can implement measurement cleanly but faces brand reckoning if measurement reveals satisfaction lower than brand claim implies (measurement may force brand repositioning).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Historical initiative records search: (1) Customer satisfaction measurement programs in project archives—have satisfaction initiatives been proposed or piloted? when? what scope? what outcomes? (past initiatives documented indicate measurement engagement, outcomes reveal implementation challenges or success enabling learning). (2) Consultant reports or external assessments mentioning satisfaction measurement—have consultants recommended satisfaction measurement? were recommendations acted upon? (consultant recommendations indicate measurement on organizational radar, action/inaction on recommendations reveals prioritization). Executive communications review: (1) Have executives discussed satisfaction measurement in internal communications? ('We should measure satisfaction' indicates awareness and consideration, 'Satisfaction measurement not feasible because...' indicates consideration and rejection, absence of satisfaction measurement discussion indicates never prioritized to executive agenda). (2) Have customer experience or customer success initiatives been discussed? (customer experience programs often include satisfaction measurement, initiative discussions would surface measurement consideration or absence). Customer success function assessment: (1) Does customer success role exist? (customer success typically owns satisfaction measurement, function existence increases likelihood measurement considered even if not implemented). (2) If customer success exists, why don't they measure satisfaction? (budget constraints, executive priority absence, past measurement attempts failed—rationale reveals decision history). Interviews with operations and customer-facing leaders: 'Why doesn't Rackspace systematically measure customer satisfaction? Has measurement been considered? What prevented implementation?' (leaders directly involved in customer experience would know measurement consideration history and absence rationale). Brand/marketing team interviews: 'How do you validate 'Fanatical Support' brand claim? How do you know customers experience fanatic support?' (brand team may reveal satisfaction measurement absence awareness and how they validate brand claim without measurement, or may be unaware satisfaction unmeasured).

uncertainty_register.unknown: Customer count reconciliation possibility and organizational capability—whether divergent customer counts could be reconciled into canonical count through organizational effort (master data management project establishing parent-subsidiary relationships, CRM data cleanup, customer definition standardization), how much organizational effort reconciliation would require (person-months, system changes, cross-functional coordination), whether reconciliation has been considered and deemed infeasible or too costly, or reconciliation possibility not evaluated (default ambiguity persists not through conscious choice but through organizational inertia)
uncertainty_register.decision_impact: Cannot assess customer count ambiguity resolution difficulty without knowing reconciliation possibility—if counts reconcilable with reasonable effort (weeks/months, standard master data management practices), ambiguity easily resolvable post-close by acquirer (ambiguity tactical gap not strategic deficit, acquirer can establish canonical count without major investment), if counts not reconcilable without extraordinary effort (years, custom system development, extensive manual cleanup), ambiguity resolution costly and time-consuming (acquirer post-close count establishment major undertaking, integration complexity from count ambiguity high). Cannot determine customer count ambiguity persistence rationale—if reconciliation considered and rejected as too costly, organization consciously tolerates ambiguity understanding effort required (functional count divergence accepted trade-off vs reconciliation cost), if reconciliation never evaluated, ambiguity persists through organizational inertia not conscious decision (reconciliation may be easier than organization assumes, ambiguity default not optimized tolerance). Cannot assess organizational master data management capability—if reconciliation requires capability organization lacks (data governance infrastructure, master data management expertise, cross-functional coordination mechanisms), capability gap broader than customer count alone (organization systematically lacks data management maturity, customer count symptom of broader capability deficit), if reconciliation requires capability organization has but hasn't applied (capability exists in pockets but not deployed to customer count problem), capability exists but prioritization or coordination gap prevents application. Cannot evaluate customer count ambiguity stakeholder impact—if financial reporting and operational counts differ materially (e.g., 20%+ difference), external stakeholders (investors) may see different customer base than operations manages (external count 1000, operational count 1200 means investors underestimate customer base scale), if difference immaterial (5% difference), ambiguity primarily internal coordination friction not stakeholder confusion. Affects acquirer customer base valuation and integration—if reconciliation difficult, acquirer must value customer base with ambiguity uncertainty discount, if reconciliation feasible, acquirer can plan count establishment as integration task with estimated cost/timeline, if counts materially diverge, acquirer must determine which count closest to economic reality for valuation (financial count likely conservative, operational count may be inflated, truth between—acquirer valuation uncertainty from divergence scale).
uncertainty_register.what_would_reduce_uncertainty: Count divergence quantification: (1) Request customer counts by methodology—financial reporting count, CRM operational count, territory planning count, delivery active customer count—multiple counts from different systems/purposes reveal divergence magnitude (counts within 5% suggests small ambiguity, counts diverging 20%+ suggests major definitional or data quality gaps). (2) Sample customer analysis—select sample customers and trace across systems: Is customer X in financial reporting? In CRM? In delivery tracking? Same customer identifier? (tracing reveals whether divergence from definitional issues—different entities counted as distinct customers—or data quality issues—same customer multiple entries). Master data management capability assessment: (1) Does Rackspace have MDM tools or expertise? (MDM capability makes reconciliation easier, capability absence means capability acquisition prerequisite to reconciliation). (2) Are parent-subsidiary customer relationships tracked anywhere? (relationship data exists somewhere makes reconciliation data-gathering exercise, relationship data absent makes reconciliation research project requiring external data acquisition or customer engagement to establish relationships). Reconciliation scoping: (1) Workshop with finance, sales operations, CRM administrators, delivery operations—bring functions together to discuss customer definition differences and reconciliation approach—workshop reveals whether reconciliation straightforward (participants quickly agree on approach) or contentious (functions have different customer concepts difficult to reconcile). (2) Scope reconciliation effort—how many customer records require review? What data enrichment needed? What systems require changes? (scoping produces effort estimate—weeks vs months vs years—and cost estimate informing reconciliation feasibility). Historical count reconciliation attempts: Has reconciliation been tried? When? Why stopped or failed? (past attempt documentation reveals reconciliation challenges learned, no attempt indicates never prioritized).

synthesis: Seven material epistemic uncertainties identified preventing definitive assessment of contradiction awareness, management, and resolution possibility. UNCERTAINTY PATTERN: Organizational decision-making and awareness levels predominantly uncertain—executive contradiction awareness uncertain (which executives know about which contradictions, whether acknowledged across executive team), Board contradiction awareness uncertain (whether Board informed of operational information quality issues and contradictions), CEO walk away policy methodology uncertain (which profitability truth CEO uses, how assessment conducted), finance adjustment communication uncertain (operations awareness of adjustment, adjustment magnitude and methodology), CRM quality tolerance rationale uncertain (explicit decision vs default inertia), satisfaction measurement absence history uncertain (considered-and-rejected vs never-considered), customer count reconciliation possibility uncertain (feasible with reasonable effort vs prohibitively complex). DECISION IMPACT CONSISTENT: All uncertainties affect M&A risk assessment materially—executive/Board awareness affects management and governance quality evaluation, CEO policy methodology affects policy sustainability assessment, finance adjustment magnitude affects operations-finance misalignment severity, CRM tolerance rationale affects data quality maturity evaluation, satisfaction measurement history affects implementation feasibility, customer count reconciliation possibility affects integration complexity and valuation uncertainty. UNCERTAINTY REDUCTION METHODS: All uncertainties reducible through targeted diligence—executive/Board interviews (awareness assessment), process documentation review (methodology and decision history visibility), historical initiative search (past attempts revealing consideration and capability), system analysis (reconciliation feasibility scoping), employee institutional memory (decision rationale and history understanding). M&A DUE DILIGENCE PRIORITY: Uncertainty reduction critical for accurate contradiction assessment—contradictions existence documented with high confidence per Stage 7.7, contradiction awareness/management/resolution remains uncertain requiring focused diligence to assess organizational contradiction sophistication (conscious management vs inadvertent tolerance), resolution feasibility (attempted-and-failed vs never-attempted affecting implementation difficulty), and accountability (who knew, who decided, who responsible for contradiction perpetuation or resolution).
